newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.
newsitem.headline: Australian Broadcasting Corp Midday Update.

text.p: COLSTON COULD STEP DOWN - SAYS OFFICE
Independent Senator Mal Colston appears set to stand down as Senate Deputy President.
The Prime Minister's demanded Senator Colston stand down, as the Government referred allegations about Senator Colston use of parliamentary entitlements to the Federal Police.
The move follows an about-face from a member of Senator Colston's staff, who previously said she was responsible for preparing the Senator's travel allowance claims.
Senator Colston's office says he's considering standing down, and will make a decision between now and when the Senate next sits.
The spokesman says the Senator had already raised the matter with friends, before Mr Howard suggested he resign.
The spokesman says Senator Colston won't be quitting Parliament.
ARL LOOKING AT SUPER LEAGUE RECONCILLIATION
The newly elected chairman of the Australian Rugby League, John McDonald, says with Ken Arthurson and John Quayle both gone from the ARL board, the relationship with Super League is improving.
John McDonald, who replaces Ken Arthurson after acting as chairman for several months, says the ARL is looking at reconcilliation with Super League.
Mr McDonald says the differences between the rival leagues, which focused on pay-TV and the media, seem to be resolving themselves steadily as the weeks go by.
DEFENCE CHIEFS WANT TIME TO IMPLEMENT CHANGES
The chiefs of Australia's Army, Navy and Air Force have asked the Prime Minister for a longer time scale to make dramatic changes to the structure for the Defence Force.
The chiefs of the Army, Navy and Air Force went to Sydney last Friday to put their case direct to John Howard, ahead of the release of the Defence Efficiency Review.
The Defence Efficiency Review -- to be released next Friday -- strips the three service heads of much of their power in favour of the Chief of the Defence Force.
NAVY GIVES AWAY "VAMPIRE"
The Navy has given away one of its most prized possessions, the Vampire.
The Daring Class Destroyer, built in 1959, was handed to the National Maritime Museum at a ceremony in Sydney today, attended by the Minister for Defence Industry, Bronwyn Bishop.
It's been on loan to the museum for the past five years.
Mrs Bishop says it's been a popular attraction.
CENTURY MEETING IN BRISBANE TODAY
The four native title claimants who have refused to sign an agreement governing the go-ahead of the massive Century Zinc project are meeting in Brisbane today.
ATSIC Deputy Chair, Ray Robinson, has refused to comment on the meeting but it's believed he'll meet the claimants in a bid to have them support the project.
